docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: At the 0. A. S. meeting in Atlanta on April 20, did Secretary of State Kissinger really believe that "We in the U. S. have come to realize that a revolution has taken place in Latin America"-that military junta takeovers there (Brazil, Uruguay, Bolivia, Ecuador and Chile-with others brewing) can be equated with revolution? And, can he believe that with
docs.abstract: Maxine Semmel lr, noting that jurors in Mitchell-Stans trial seem to have acquitted defendants not because they thought men to be innocent but because Govt failed to prove its case beyond reasonable doubt, suggests adopting Scottish system of returning a decision of 'not proven' in such cases

docs.snippet: Not so long ago, Uruguay was proud of its culture, its high level of literacy, the freedom of its press. Three distinguished French poets (Lautreamont, Laforgue, Supervielle) had been born there. Some of its essayists (like Rod6), and its novelists...
docs.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, Uruguay was proud of its culture, its high level of literacy, the freedom of its press. Three distinguished French poets (Lautreamont, Laforgue, Supervielle) had been born there. Some of its essayists (like Rod6), and its novelists and playwrights (Florencio Sanchez, Quiroga, Onetti) had achieved international fame.
docs.abstract: Suzanne Jill Levine article revs pol background to Uruguayan Govt's closing down of leading leftist critical journal Marcha and imprisoning of its editors Hugo Alfaro and Juan Carlos Onetti, central figure in development of Latin Amer novel; illus (M)

headline.main: Last Battle for a Free Press in Uruguay; The Guest Word

docs.snippet: Uruguayan novelist Juan Carlos Onetti and dirs of leftist weekly, Marcha, are freed on May 14; have been imprisoned since Feb for publishing short story considered critical of police (S)
docs.abstract: Uruguayan novelist Juan Carlos Onetti and dirs of leftist weekly, Marcha, are freed on May 14; have been imprisoned since Feb for publishing short story considered critical of police (S)

docs.snippet: To the Editor: In his analysis of U.S.-Latin American relations [letter May 8], A. J. Rosenstein contends that in "at least five major Latin-American countries a majority of the people do not consider themselves our partners."
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his analysis of U.S.-Latin American relations [letter May 8], A. J. Rosenstein contends that in "at least five major Latin-American countries a majority of the people do not consider themselves our partners."
docs.abstract: Abraham Engelman lr opposes bill authorizing NYC to transfer $70-million from expense to capital budget in order to make transportation improvements; contends city is borrowing its way into bankruptcy

headline.main: Letters to the Editor; Latin America: A Different Revolution

docs.snippet: Uruguay's 22,000-man army went on alert today, apparently as a way to force President Juan Maria Bordaberry to oust his Minister of Economy, sources close to the Government said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay's 22,000-man army went on alert today, apparently as a way to force President Juan Maria Bordaberry to oust his Minister of Economy, sources close to the Government said.
docs.abstract: 22,000-man Uruguayan army goes on alert, apparently as way to force Pres Juan Maria Brodaberry to oust Econ Min Moises Cohen and 2 other unidentified min officials; Bordaberry's yielding to rebellious mil officers in Feb, '73, adopting their program for econ change and adm reform noted; army reptdly has told Pres to modify Cabinet (S)

headline.main: Minister's Ouster In Uruguay Is Seen Aim of Army Alert

docs.snippet: President Juan M. Bordaberry, who has jointly ruled Uruguay with the military over the last year, is again under pressure from army leaders frustrated by the country's deepening economic crisis.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Juan M. Bordaberry, who has jointly ruled Uruguay with the military over the last year, is again under pressure from army leaders frustrated by the country's deepening economic crisis.
docs.abstract: Uruguayan Pres Juan M Bordaberry is reptdly under pressure from army leaders frustrated by country's deepening econ crisis; commanding army garrisons officers to force resignation of army commander Gen Hugo Chiappe, who reptdly opposes complete mil take-over of Govt; Bordaberry reptdly agrees to overhaul Cabinet in next few days to avert further confrontation with hard-line officers led by Gen Esteban Cristi, who has temporarily assumed command while remaining head of army garrison at Montevideo; Gen Julio Vadora, Uruguay's army attache in Washington, apptd new Commander-in-Chief and will return to Uruguay in June; mil has become increasingly dominant in pol since it was called on to crush Tupamaros movement at beginning of decade; conflict between mil and Bordaberry discussed; mil is strongly critical of Agr Min Benito Medero and Finance Min Moises Cohen; country's econ problems have been exacerbated by shortages, worsening trade balance and inflationary measures; pol crisis appears to have aroused little pub interest since newspapers have been under censorship for several mos; por of Cristi (M)

headline.main: URUGUAY'S ARMY FORCING CHANGES; Economic Crisis Bringing Pressure on President for Cabinet Shuffle

docs.snippet: Brazil and Bolivia signed an economic cooperation pact today amid growing changes of Brazilian expansionism.
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil and Bolivia signed an economic cooperation pact today amid growing changes of Brazilian expansionism.
docs.abstract: Brazilian Pres Gen Ernesto Geisel and Bolivian Pres Hugo Banzer Suarez sign pact providing for sale of Bolivian natural gas to Brazil and construction of $600-million gas pipeline between 2 countries (S)

headline.main: Brazilian-Bolivian Trade Pact Signed Amid Protests in La Paz; Iron Ore Development

docs.snippet: Pope Paul VI appealed to world governments today to consider granting amnesty to prisoners, especially those held for political crimes.
docs.lead_paragraph: Pope Paul VI appealed to world governments today to consider granting amnesty to prisoners, especially those held for political crimes.
docs.abstract: Pope Paul VI, in papal bull May 23, proclaiming '75 Holy Yr, appeals to world govts to consider granting amnesty to prisoners, especially those held for pol crimes (S)

headline.main: Pope, Proclaiming 1975 a Holy Year, Calls for Amnesty
